title: 110_hr4112
content: 15-year recovery period for depreciation of designated low-income buildings. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new clause regarding designated low-income buildings. A designated low-income building is defined as a qualified low-income building with specific criteria. The taxpayer can make an irrevocable election for a building without a housing credit allocation under section 42(h). This election must be made as prescribed by the Secretary. No low-income housing credit is allowed for designated low-income buildings. During the recapture period, a designated low-income building that no longer qualifies as such will be subject to recapture of accelerated depreciation. The assessment of any deficiency must be made within one year of notifying the Secretary of the change in status. During the recapture period, a designated low-income building may be subject to recapture of accelerated depreciation if it no longer qualifies. The assessment of any deficiency must be made within one year of notifying the Secretary of the change in status. The compliance period for this recapture is 20 taxable years instead of 15. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. Qualified low-income buildings are not subject to limitation on passive activity losses and credits. The amendment to Section 469 of the Internal Revenue Code exempts qualified low-income buildings from limitations on passive activity losses and credits. This applies to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. The amendment to Section 469 of the Internal Revenue Code reorders the ordering rules for passive activity losses and credits, specifying the application process for different scenarios. The effective date for these amendments is specified. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act.
